Ringkasan dari artikel: Summary 1. Install distcc on all the machines that you want to use for compilation. 2. Start the distcc daemon on each of these machines. 3. Export the DISTCC_HOSTS environment variable with their names. 4. Start the distcc monitor (so you can see what's going on!). 5. Instead of configuring with: ./configure, use CC=distcc ./configure. 6. Instead of making with make or make -j 2, use make -j n, where n is two or three times the number of machines in DISTCC_HOSTS. If you have programs that would benefit from optimization, then "rolling your own" binaries from the source code is the way to go. This can be comparatively expensive in terms of wall-clock time for larger builds, so using distcc allows you (and everyone else) to mop up those idle CPU cycles on the network and get up and running as quickly as possible.

Pizzabox tu sebenarnya ialah kotak pembungkus pizzahut (takeaway) yang didalamnya terdapat pizza berperisa hawaiian chicken yang menungu saat2 untuk dibaham, ataupon dalam bahasa jawa yer, the box that allow ADSL signals to pass thru fiber optic networks. Some interesting info pasal pizzabox ni yg aku jumpa kat urlLink forum.mypdacafe.com : StreamyX utilises DSL. DSL is a copper based Last Mile technology, that means that DSL is the system that connects the enduser to a central point, within a maximum 18,000ft or 5.4km radius via standard copper lines, after which, another conenction type takes over. DSL is ONLY used as a last mile conenction because it works by modulating data on to a high frequency electrical carrier signel and thus is impracticle to use over long distances. Where as fibre was designed to carry high amounts of data perfectly over long distances. So in the grand scheme of things over here, StreamyX works by connecting your house to the DSLAM a.k.a PizzaBox located in a Telekom office via a copper connection, afterwhich, the DSLAM is connected to the Internet (not as simple, but you get the idea) via a fibre medium connection. What Telekom is trying to tell you is either, there are no fibre cables to service a DSLAM in your area, or they have run out of fibre connections in your area to service a new DSLAM, for additional DSL ports. Now. When they say that your area can NOT have DSL because your phone line is served by fibre, it actualy means that instead of there being a fully copper connection leading from you to the telekom office where the DSLAM is, your house is connected to a junction box via copper (Analog), then the junction box is connected to the telekom office via fibre (Digital) before it's converted back to copper (Analog) for PTSN switching. DSL signals cannot survive the analog-digital-analog conversion that occurs when a junction box is served by fibre, as per the above senario. There can be a junction box between you and the office, but it cannot be served by fibre for DSL to work.

What is a diskless machine? A diskless machine is a PC without any of the usual boot devices such as hard disks, floppy drives or CD-ROMs. The diskless node boots off the network and needs a server that will provide it with storage space as a local hard disk would. From now on we call the server the master , while the diskless machine gets called the slave (what's in a name :). The slave node needs a network adapter that supports PXE booting or Etherboot; check urlLink Etherboot.org for support listings. Most modern cards support PXE and many built-in adapters on motherboards will also work. urlLink more >>

About openMosix OpenMosix is a patch to the Linux kernel that allows multiple hosts to act as a single system image (SSI). This results in multiple hosts appearing as one large multiprocessor host. At the time of writing the latest release of the openMosix kernel patch is version 2.4.22, and the openMosix user tools has version 0.3.4. There is a wide variety of information about openMosix at urlLink http://openmosix.sourceforge.net . It is not easy to cluster different versions of patched kernel sources, and we have found that most patches are not backwards compatible. OpenMosix migrates heavy weight processes explicitly when executing a.out or ELF binaries or when a heavy weight process forks. It will not migrate light weight processes such as p-threads, or heavyweight processes that use shared memory. For more information about openMosix visit their urlLink home page . About the cluster Our cluster will be composed of individual computers (nodes) sharing computational resources in an effort to increase the computational power of all nodes. Not all nodes need to be of the same architecture but that makes the task of clustering them much easier. urlLink more >>
